meanings.definition: To tame or train (an animal) to live in close association with and be of use to humans.
meanings.sent1: Farmers domesticate cows to provide milk and meat for their families.
meanings.sent2: People domesticate dogs to be loyal companions and protectors.
meanings.sent3: The zookeeper joked that he would domesticate the monkeys to help with the gardening.
meanings.sent4: She managed to domesticate her fear of public speaking and gave a confident presentation.
meanings.sent5: The ancient Egyptians were known to domesticate cats to keep their homes free of pests.

meanings.definition: To adapt (a plant) to grow in a human environment.
meanings.sent1: Gardeners domesticate roses to thrive in different climates and soil conditions.
meanings.sent2: Botanists domesticate various crops to ensure a bountiful harvest each year.
meanings.sent3: The houseplant seemed to domesticate itself, growing happily in any room it was placed in.
meanings.sent4: Her love for gardening helped her domesticate even the most delicate flowers in her backyard.
meanings.sent5: The ancient civilization learned to domesticate wheat, revolutionizing their agricultural practices.
